bleed.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to lose blood, especially because of an injury
bleed.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Mrs Burke was found unconscious and bleeding profusely.
bleed.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to take some blood from someone’s body, done in the past in order to treat a disease
bleed.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: When he fell sick several days later, he had a doctor bleed him.
bleed.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to force someone to pay an unreasonable amount of money over a period of time
bleed.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: His ex-wife clearly intends to bleed him for every last penny.
The ten-year war has bled the country dry.
bleed.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to remove air or liquid from a system in order to make it work properly, for example from a heating system
bleed.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: We need to bleed the radiators.
bleed.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to spread from one area of cloth or paper to another
bleed.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: Wash it in cold water so the colours don’t bleed.
bleed.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Its consumer electronics division continued to bleed, with an operating loss of $100 million.
bleed.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to make someone pay an unreasonable amount of money
bleed.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: She bled him for every last cent that she could.
bleed.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to take a lot or all of someone’s money
bleed.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: developing countries bled dry by massive loan repayments
